g.text: -a < ε < a for every positive real number a.
Positive but less than every positive real number.
Negative but greater than every negative real number.
The real numbers form a subset of the hyperreal numbers,
and the order relation x < y for the real numbers is a
subset of the order relation for hyperreal numbers.
There is a hyperreal number that is greater than zero
but less than every positive real number.
For every real function f of one or more variables
we are given a corresponding hyperreal function
f* of the same number of variables.
f* is called the natural extension of f.
Every real statement that holds for one or more particular
real functions holds for the hyperreal natural extensions of these functions.
A combination of equations or inequalities about real expressions,
and statements specifying whether a real expression is defined or undefined.
Every finite hyperreal number is infinitely close to exactly one real number.
The only infinitesimal real number is 0.
b + ε is finite but not infinitesimal.
H + ε and H + b are infinite.
δ * ε and b * ε are infinitesimal.
b * c is finite but not infinitesimal.
H * b and H * K are infinite.
ε/b, ε/H and b/H are infinitesimal.
b/c is finite but not infinitesimal.
b/ε, H/ε and H/b are infinite, provided that ε ≠ 0.
If b > 0, b^(1/n) is finite but not infinitesimal.
ε/δ, the quotient of two infinitesimals.
H/K, the quotient of two infinite numbers.
Hε, the product of an infinite and an infinitesimal.
H + K, the sum of two infinite numbers.
Every hyperreal number which is between two
Every hyperreal number which is between two
Every hyperreal number which is greater than some
positive infinite number is positive infinite.
Every hyperreal number which is less than some
negative infinite number is negative infinite.
Two hyperreal numbers b and c are said to be infinitely close to each other,
in symbols b ≈ c, if their difference b - c is infinitesimal.
b ≉ c means that b is not infinitely close to c.
If ε is infinitesimal, then b ≈ b + ε.
b is infinitesimal if and only if b ≈ 0.
If b and c are real and b is infinitely close to c,
If a ≈ b, then b ≈ a.
If a ≈ b and b ≈ c, then a ≈ c.
If a is infinitesimal, so is b.
If a is finite, so is b.
If a is infinite, so is b.
Let b be a finite hyperreal number, the standard part of b,
denoted by st(b), is the real number which is infinitely close to b.
Infinite hyperreal numbers do not have standard parts.
b = st(b) + ε for some infinitesimal ε.
If b is real, then b = st(b).
If st(b) ≠ 0, then st(a/b) = st(a) / st(b).
If a ≤ b, then st(a) ≤ st(b).
